document.title: Cevi Clock
document.description: Small project for a cevi camp

body.raw:
![Cevi Clock](/images/cevi-clock.png)

A unique digital clock that showcases the passage of time with an added twist. Built using React and TypeScript, this clock follows the usual time progression but makes a significant leap every day.


At its core, the Time Offset Clock functions as a regular digital clock, displaying the current hours, minutes, and seconds.
As the clock hits 21:00 (9 PM), instead of smoothly transitioning to the next hour, it leaps forward by three hours. This results in a sudden jump, taking the display time straight to 00:00.
The 3-hour offset accumulates each day. So, on the second day, when it reaches 21:00, the clock jumps to 03:00, on the third day to 06:00, and so on.
Designed to be distraction-free, the clock uses a full-screen interface, making it perfect for wall projections or as a standalone time display tool.

### Why this project?

This project was build for a cevi camp with a unique twist. The clock is used to display the time during the camp.
The activities are planned around the time jumps and the campers are encouraged to guess the time.
That means that they could be going to bed when the outside world is just waking up.

[//]: # (**Project Description**:)

[//]: # (A unique digital clock that showcases the passage of time with an added twist. Built using React and TypeScript, this clock follows the usual time progression but makes a significant leap every day.)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (### Features:)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (1. **Dynamic Time Display**:)

[//]: # (At its core, the Time Offset Clock functions as a regular digital clock, displaying the current hours, minutes, and seconds.)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (2. **Time Offset**:)

[//]: # (As the clock hits 21:00 (9 PM), instead of smoothly transitioning to the next hour, it leaps forward by three hours. This results in a sudden jump, taking the display time straight to 00:00.)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (3. **Continuous Offset**:)

[//]: # (The 3-hour offset accumulates each day. So, on the second day, when it reaches 21:00, the clock jumps to 03:00, on the third day to 06:00, and so on.)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (4. **Full-screen Display**:)

[//]: # (Designed to be distraction-free, the clock uses a full-screen interface, making it perfect for wall projections or as a standalone time display tool.)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (### Technologies Used:)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (- **React**: A JavaScript library for building the UI, making it highly responsive and efficient.)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (- **TypeScript**: Enhances the JavaScript codebase, providing static type definitions which ensure type safety, better refactoring, and a more descriptive codebase.)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (- **CSS**: Provides the styling, ensuring a readable display and elegant transitions.)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (### Why this project?)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (This project was build for a cevi camp with a unique twist. The clock is used to display the time during the camp.)

[//]: # (The activities are planned around the time jumps and the campers are encouraged to guess the time.)

[//]: # (That means that they could be going to bed when the outside world is just waking up.)

body.raw:
This is the website you're looking at. It's built with [Next.js](https://nextjs.org/) and [Tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/).
It was my first time using next.js and I really enjoyed it. I'm not a huge fan of React, but next.js makes it a lot easier to work with.
It's hosted on [Vercel](https://vercel.com/).

I got the initial project from [chronark](https://github.com/chronark/chronark.com) and then I modified it to my needs.
Huge thanks to him for the initial design and the inspiration.

[//]: # (Like so many others, I just wanted a place to collect some projects I worked on. Maybe I'll add a blog, maybe I won't. I'm not sure yet.)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (If you like the design, check out the Repository on GitHub.)

document.title: Intellij File Finder Plugin
document.description: Intellij Plugin for searching similar files in a project

body.raw:
[![](/images/intellij-file-finder.png)](https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/21134-file-finder) The File Finder is a plugin designed to help developers quickly find files in their project. The primary feature of this plugin is to locate associated files in your project structure. With a double-click of the mouse, you can easily navigate to an associated file. The plugin uses an intelligent algorithm to extract the name of the current file you are working on and searches for other files based on that name. For instance, if you are working on a file named "UserController.java," the plugin will extract the name "User" and search for other files with that name. The Project Files Finder plugin also comes with a customizable search location and search pattern feature that enables developers to customize their search to match their specific project requirements. Key Features:
  • Quickly locate associated files in your project structure
  • Customizable search locations and search pattern
  • Simple, one-click navigation to associated files
  • Enhance productivity by reducing search time
The Files Finder plugin is an essential tool for any developer who wants to streamline their workflow and enhance their productivity. With its powerful features and easy-to-use interface, this plugin is a must-have for any development team.

document.title: Maze Generator and Solver
document.description: A maze generator and solver implemented in Java.

body.raw:
This project represents a maze generator and solver implemented in Java. It uses a classic algorithm based on cell visitation and a stack to remember the path to generate and then solve the maze.

- It supports a fixed grid size, which is initialized during object creation.
- It has the ability to either generate or solve a maze.
- While generating the maze, it uses a stack (`history`) to keep track of the visited cells.
- While solving the maze, it identifies neighboring cells and then determine the solution path.
- The resulting maze is passed to the `Drawer` class for visualization.

Each cell in the maze is represented by an enum, which can have one of the following values:
- `PATH`: Represents a navigable path.
- `WALL`: Represents a wall or barrier.
- `VISITED`: Represents a cell that has been visited during maze generation/solution.
- `CORRECT`: Represents the correct path of the maze solution.

The maze can also be visualized using a `BufferedImage`, which is then saved as a PNG file.
- Renders the maze to an image, which can then be saved.
- Can optionally highlight the solution path in a different color.

### Key Features:

1. **Maze Generation**: The maze is generated using an iterative approach. As cells are visited, their type is updated, and their position is stored in a stack. This helps in tracing back if a dead-end is encountered.

2. **Maze Solver**: Once the maze has been generated, the solver can be run to determine the solution path. This solution path is again determined using an iterative approach and can be visualized in the final rendered image.

3. **Visualization**: The maze (with or without the solution path) is visualized using a `BufferedImage`, which is then saved as a PNG file.


[//]: # (## Improvements and Considerations:)

[//]: # ()
[//]: # (1. **Error Handling**: Currently, simple error messages are displayed for certain conditions (like entering a value less than 1). This can be expanded for more robust error handling and user feedback.)

[//]: # (2. **Customization**: Additional features can be added for customizing the maze (like specifying the start and end points, having multiple solutions, etc.).)

[//]: # (3. **Performance**: The maze generation and solution can be optimized for larger grid sizes. Consideration can also be given to the efficiency of image rendering, especially for larger mazes.)

document.title: Swissbanking Migration
document.description: Migration of the content of the old Swissbanking website to the new one.

body.raw:
Migration of the content of the old Swissbanking website to the improved new one.
This project was done in a small team at [Noser Young](https://noseryoung.ch/) in 2021.
We worked together with the client to correctly migrate the content.
The project was done in a month and was a great learning experience.

![Certificate of Gratitude](/images/swiss-banking-certificate-of-gratitude.jpg)
